title: Lujvo vs Tanru
goal: Understand when to use lujvo versus tanru.

sections.content:
Warm-up (2-3 min)

Review all 8 new words so far:

brivla → ?     glibau → ?
cmavo → ?      selsku → ?
lujvo → ?      seljmi → ?
jbobau → ?     terdi → ?

(Answers: predicate word, English, structure word, what is said, compound word, what is understood, Lojban, Earth)

New Material (5-7 min)

Lujvo = Fixed Meaning

Lujvo have standardized, dictionary definitions.

jbobau always means "the Lojban language." brivla always means "predicate word."

Tanru = Contextual Meaning

Tanru have loose, context-dependent meanings.

lojbo bangu could mean:

  • Lojbanic language
  • Language for Lojban speakers
  • Language about Lojban
  • etc.

Comparison Table

Feature Tanru Lujvo
Form Separate words Single fused word
Meaning Vague, contextual Fixed, precise
Creation Anyone, anytime Standardized process
Example lojbo bangu jbobau

When to Use Which

Use lujvo when:

  • A standard compound exists
  • You want a precise, known meaning
  • The concept is common

Use tanru when:

  • No lujvo exists for your concept
  • You want creative/novel expression
  • The meaning is clear from context

Examples

mi tavla fo la jbobau

I speak in Lojban. (Using the standard lujvo)

ti lojbo se cusku

This is a Lojbanic utterance. (Novel tanru, no standard lujvo)

Key Point

Lujvo are frozen tanru with fixed meanings. Use lujvo for common concepts, tanru for novel descriptions.
sections.title: New Material (5-7 min)

sections.content:
Practice (4-5 min)

Exercise 1: Lujvo or Tanru?

Identify which is better for each:

  1. "English language" (common concept)
  2. "blue-dog house" (novel description)
  3. "Lojban" (common concept)
  4. "fast-running dog" (description)
Answers
  1. Lujvo: glibau
  2. Tanru: blanu gerku zdani
  3. Lujvo: jbobau
  4. Tanru: sutra bajra gerku

Exercise 2: Find the Difference

What's the difference between:

  1. jbobau vs lojbo bangu
  2. brivla vs bridi valsi
Answers

  1. jbobau = fixed meaning "Lojban language" lojbo bangu = loose tanru "Lojbanic language / language related to Lojban"

  2. brivla = fixed meaning "predicate word" bridi valsi = loose tanru "predicate word / word about predicates"

Exercise 3: Choose Appropriately

Translate using lujvo where available:

  1. I speak Lojban.
  2. This is a predicate word.
  3. I see a big blue dog. (novel description)
Answers
  1. mi tavla fo la jbobau (lujvo)
  2. ti brivla (lujvo)
  3. mi viska la barda blanu gerku (tanru — no lujvo for this)

items.text: I see a big blue dog. (novel description)
items.answer: `mi viska la barda blanu gerku` (tanru — no lujvo for this)

sections.content:
Conversation Challenge (1-2 min)

Say aloud:

  1. "I learn Lojban." → mi cilre la jbobau
  2. "I speak English." → mi tavla fo la glibau
  3. "This is a structure word." → ti cmavo

Today's Vocab

Review — no new words today.

Decision guide:

If... Use...
Standard compound exists Lujvo
Novel/creative description Tanru
Common, precise concept Lujvo
Context makes meaning clear Either works

Summary

You learned to distinguish lujvo (fixed meanings) from tanru (contextual meanings). Use lujvo for common concepts, tanru for novel descriptions.
